abstract.p: A field study was conducted to investigate the thermal environment and occupants’ comfort in the National Museum of Malaysia. The occupants’ thermal perceptions in the museum were measured and characterised. The response of the occupants has indicated that the thermal conditions inside the museum did not satisfactorily fulfil the ASHRAE Standard 55, because only 78% of the occupants were satisfied with their environment. Besides, actual mean vote (AMV) and predicted mean vote (PMV) were compared. The Fanger’s model gave a neutral operative temperature of 22.2°C from the PMV, whereas the questionnaire data used in the mean thermal sensation vote (MTSV) of the present study gave a higher value (22.5°C) for the neutral operative temperature. The preferred operative temperature was found to be 22.3°C. The minimum air temperature in three galleries was below the lower limit of the temperature range of 18–22°C as recommended by Museums Australia Victoria. The mean indoor humidity was too high compared to the optimal range of 55 ± 5% relative humidity (RH). The mean air velocity, ≤0.15 m·s−1, in each gallery was satisfactory. Findings of this study are very useful for designing heating, ventilating and air-conditioning (HVAC) systems with energy-saving methodology for museum buildings in tropical regions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The objective of temperature and climate control in a museum is the prevention and limitation of the degradation process of the artefacts firstly, while at the same time ensuring a pleasant environment for the occupants. Thermal-hygrometric parameters and air ventilation effectiveness are of significant importance for the indoor microclimatic conditions of the exhibition rooms of museum buildings. An appropriate heating, ventilating and air-conditioning (HVAC) system is needed for precise control of temperature, humidity and air velocity. The HVAC system minimises fluctuations of these parameters from their design values, in order to develop a safe and suitable environment required for the exhibits and the occupants. Potentially harmful variations of the microclimatic conditions are caused by thermal load due to ventilated outdoor air and thermal load due to occupants present in the exhibition spaces especially in Malaysia [1,2], the latter being highly variable according to the occupant numbers [3].

Malaysia is a tropical country. Therefore, museum buildings demand the continuous cooling operation of the air-conditioning system, almost throughout the whole year and for 24 h a day. Consequently, the control strategies for heating and humidification can be ignored. Sustainability based on a socio-economic context is useful for achieving considerable energy savings, while maintaining a good dynamic microclimatic control [3–6].

Museum buildings are significant in their representation of national cultural heritage and their functional character. It is difficult to establish a balance between the necessary indoor climatic conditions for protecting the exhibits and providing thermal comfort to the occupants, while also showing respect to the aesthetics and the historical significance of the buildings. In order to evaluate the cooling loads, assessing the building’s thermal conductivity and capacity, necessary ventilation and indoor air movement are essential [7].

Referring to Lim, Malaysia is a country where the people have to live with a constantly hot and humid climate [8]. Throughout the year, the temperature ranges from 22 to 32°C in the lowlands. Two distinct seasons exist in Malaysia. The south-west monsoon creates the dry season from May to September and the rainy season caused by the north-east monsoon prevails from mid-November until March. A heavy shower often accompanied by thunder and lightning usually lasts for about an hour or two on a rainy day. Annual rainfall is heavy at 2,500 mm and the relative humidity (RH) level is about 80% throughout the year. It is, therefore, a necessity for most of the museums to have an air-conditioning (A/C) system to control the indoor air quality (IAQ) for preservation of the artefacts.

Muzium Negara is the National Museum of Malaysia located on Damansara Road in Kuala Lumpur. It was built in a palatial structure. It consists of three storeys in a structure of 109.7 m in length, 15.1 m in width and 37.6 m in height at the central point. There are four main galleries in the museum specializing in ethnology and natural history. The displays are free-standing tableaux of cultural events like weddings, festivals and costumes and also traditional weapons, musical instruments, arts and crafts, ceramics and flora and fauna.

Indoor environmental control is important to take care of all of these collections. The main causes of degradation processes of historical building and works of art are thermal-hygrometric conditions, vertical thermal distribution of air masses, air-velocity in contact with the artefacts, IAQ, concentration of pollutants and electromagnetic radiation emanating from sources of artificial and natural light [9]. Degradation can also be induced by their synergic effects [10].

Degradation phenomena due to changes of size and form of objects by mechanical mechanisms, chemical reactions and proliferation of microorganisms are the major risks to the collection of cultural heritage [3]. Hence, all limitations must be defined at the beginning of the design. Stable RH and operative temperature are important to prevent collections from deterioration and to provide a suitable environment for comfort and health of visitors.

All materials change their size due to their properties when subjected to a change of temperature and RH. Materials get fractured easily if the temperature is too low and chemical processes occur more quickly at elevated temperatures. High temperature also accelerates ageing or decay. Biological deterioration may also occur in the collection. Lower temperature is associated with higher RH. This improves growth conditions for microbial organisms. Hence, caution must be taken to control the temperature of the museum to be within a suitable range. The most important factors with regard to damage to the collections are the indoor temperature and RH of the museum.

Most museums require a RH of 40–55% and a temperature of 18–24°C, with daily fluctuations of ±3% RH and ±3°C, respectively. A filtration design is necessary to remove at least 50% of particulates and contaminants in order to achieve comfort and health [11]. For general museums, the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air Conditioning Engineering (ASHRAE) Handbook 2007 recommends a temperature range of 15–25°C and a RH of less than 60% [12].

According to Plenderleith and Werner, the museum room temperature suitable for the occupants within the limits of 16–25°C should be determined first, and then the RH should be decided with regard to the collections [13]. Thomson suggests an upper and lower limit of RH of 65% and 45% for moisture-absorbing materials [14]. Ascione [3] and Bellia [15] suggest an air temperature of 22 ± 1°C and 50 ± 5% RH for exhibition rooms. The Museums Australia Victoria recommends that the temperature range for a museum should be 18–22°C [16]. Temperatures lower than 18°C put museum collections at risk. The lower level of the temperature range is decided by the comfort of the museum staff and visitors. It is more difficult to maintain the recommended humidity level when the temperature is below 10°C, and there may be problems associated with condensation. The higher the temperature level, the faster the degradation processes. Thus, the people’s comfort and the preservation of the collections determine the temperature range of 18–22°C. The temperature of the areas seldom visited by staff and visitors may be kept lower (in cases where heating is required).

Besides indoor air temperature and RH, effective outdoor air ventilation is necessary for providing a comfortable environment for the occupants. Excessive flow of outdoor air could lead to particle and gaseous pollution. Furthermore, it would cause an unreasonably high latent heat load in a humid climate and, thereby, cause unacceptably high energy consumption. Thus, outside air flow should be kept to the minimum required for supplying fresh air to the occupants and pressurizing the collection areas. It is advisable to keep the outdoor air flow rate lower than the maximum limit of 0.25 m·s−1 recommended by the ASHRAE Standard 55 [17].

This research aims to provide:
Measurement and characterization of occupants’ thermal perceptions in a museum in Malaysia.
Comparison between predicted and observed values of the percentage of the occupants dissatisfied.
Determination of the acceptable neutral temperature in the museum.
Measurement of the indoor thermal environmental parameters by sensors.
Determination of strategies in designing HVAC systems with low energy consumption for a thermally comfortable environment expected by the occupants of museum buildings in the tropics.

sec.title: Theory on Thermal Comfort
sec.p: Thermal comfort standards play a great role in building sustainability as these are the determining factors for energy consumption of a building’s environmental systems. Thermal comfort is a measurement of the level of comfort of the indoor environment as perceived by the occupants, and gives an indication of the proportion of occupants that notice warmth or coolness in a space. The classical approach, called the T–RH method, of controlling or measuring air temperature and humidity is not practically feasible for the assessment of the museum’s environment. People’s thermal comfort depends on both personal and environmental factors. The parameters that determine indoor thermal conditions are mainly temperature and sensation indices.

Fanger created the predicted mean vote (PMV) model to determine the thermal comfort conditions for working and living spaces. Based on thermo-neutrality, the PMV model expresses the mean value of the votes by a large group of persons on a seven-point thermal scale, which describes the thermal perceptions of the occupants. The PMV index is a function of four environmental parameters – air temperature, partial pressure of water vapour, relative air velocity and mean radiant temperature, and two environmental parameters – metabolic rate and clothing insulation.

Assuming steady-state laboratory conditions in its derivation, the PMV model makes an oversimplification of its sensitivity to the metabolic rates and the clo-values. Thus, thermal impressions are underestimated and the swings of these impressions get undervalued. Transitional spaces are excluded for thermal comfort predictions by the PMV model as the physical conditions and the met values are unstable and dynamic in nature [18]. The psychological and the behavioural adaptations in the real world are not considered in the PMV model [19].

The PMV equation is only applicable where human beings remain at constant conditions for a long period with a constant metabolic rate. The PMV model does not give good results due to inaccurate specifications of some of its input parameters. Buratti and Ricciardi collected data by experimental measurements with special microclimatic acquisition systems and also distributed a series of specific questions to respondents. Comparison of PMV values obtained from both the cases showed that the information gathered from the questionnaire has a tendency to overestimate/estimate higher discomfort conditions [20]. Becker and Paciuk reported that the PMVs calculated by the Fanger’s PMV model were markedly lower than the actual thermal sensation votes [21].

Because of the inaccuracy of the PMV model, the adaptive predicted mean vote (aPMV) model, based on different conditions, was created. According to van Hoof, there are two ways for improvement: one is the correction or adjustment of the model itself, and the other is the introduction of methods to increase the accuracy of input parameters of the model [18]. Humphreys and Nicol clarified how the variables used in the calculation of PMV cause the difference between the actual vote and the PMV [22].

Based on the different opinions for a warm climate leading to disagreement between the actual mean vote (AMV) and the PMV, Fanger and Toftum placed an extended PMV model with the incorporation of an “expectancy factor, e”. This mainly explains that in a warm climate, a discrepancy occurs between the AMV and the PMV for naturally ventilated buildings due to overestimation of the PMV for thermal sensation of the occupants. Conventional heat-balance theory applied to laboratory research gives rise to the thermal index of PMV, which could become widely applied with the help of this expectancy factor [23].

Besides that, Yao et al. also proposed an aPMV model, which is expressed by Equation (1) where “λ” is termed as the “adaptive coefficient” [19]. (1)aPMV=PMV1+λ×PMV. This aPMV model explicitly describes how ISO 7730 overestimates or underestimates thermal sensation occurring in the heat-balance model of PMV in warm and cool conditions, respectively. It is a linear regression model expressing the relationship between indoor design temperature or an acceptable range of temperature and outdoor meteorological parameters.

Comfort zones are defined by the International Standards ISO 7730 [24] and the ASHRAE Standard 55-92 [25] by the application of Fanger’s lab-oriented PMV-predicted percent dissatisfied (PPD) method. The thermal comfort standard by adaptive thermal comfort has been claimed to be energy saving in comparison to that by the traditional PMV–PPD-based thermal comfort [26]. This led to the update of the ASHRAE Standard 55 by the Adaptive Comfort Standard American National Standard Institute (ANSI)/ASHRAE 55-2004 [17].

The adaptive principle of thermal comfort requires a field-survey for collecting data on the thermal environment as well as thermal responses of the subjects. A statistically significant relationship between the indoor air temperature and the indoor neutral temperature was found by Humpreys [19]. The outdoor climate significantly influences the prevailing indoor air temperature. The adaptive model shows that the thermal comfort temperature is a function of the outdoor air temperature.

According to Brager and de Dear, the PMV and the AMV established from the subjects’ responses are complementary to each other [27], and the thermal and non-thermal effects on occupants’ responses in real buildings can only be estimated by creating a compromise between both types of modelling approaches [19,26]. The aPMV model is helpful for applying the PMV method in various buildings with the consideration of the local climate, culture and social backgrounds, as well as behavioural habits, styles and so on. The aPMV model is also useful for studying the dynamic thermal comfort set points, which are some of the key factors that affect building energy consumption.

sec.title: Methodology
sec.p: A museum preserves the displayed materials and also provides thermal comfort to the visitors and the employees simultaneously. With a view to measuring and characterizing occupants’ thermal perceptions in the Muzium Negara, the National Museum located in Kuala Lumpur in Malaysia, a field study was conducted using a subjective questionnaire survey and also thermal–environmental parameter monitoring. The aim of the subjective measurement was to determine the discrepancies between the subjects’ AMV and Fanger’s equation based on PMV. The statistical analysis led to the implementation of a practical thermal comfort temperature.

sec.title: Subjective Measurement
sec.p: In the museum, 28 subjects were chosen in four different galleries during field measurement. The participants were 8 females (28.57%) and 20 males (71.43%). Their mean age was 23.71 years with an age range of 22–28 years. A total of five males and two females were selected from each gallery.

The thermal–environmental survey had covered several demographics such as name, gender, age and so on. The ASHRAE seven-points Thermal Sensation Scale (TSENS), current clothing garment and metabolic activity checklist also had been included in the survey. Figure 1 shows the questionnaire on the thermal environment and occupants’ thermal comfort that was distributed to the subjects participating in the study. The TSENS was used to simulate occupants’ thermal response to their environment; the scale for the rating was as follows: hot (3), warm (2), slightly warm (1), neutral (0), slightly cool (−1), cool (−2) and cold (−3). Table 1 shows a descriptive summary of the subject occupants participated in the questionnaire in the four galleries in the National Museum. sec.title: Results and Discussion
sec.p: Bioclimatic, environmentally friendly and energy-conscious design is crucial in most museums. The sustainability factors of museums can be improved by a better exhibition of the display materials with maximum visual, acoustic and thermal comfort and a better IAQ. A lower energy consumption with reduced respective operational costs is preferable, but the minimization must not be given prime importance.

The ISO 7730 awards the PMV of the occupants’ thermal sensation a higher value on the ASHRAE scale in the warm conditions of the tropics, since the PMV model does not account for the psychological and behavioural adaptations in the real world. This leads to an excessive use of A/C, thus increasing energy consumption.

The AMV was determined from the subjects’ questionnaire survey. Obviously, the neutral operative temperature calculated by the AMV is higher than that calculated by the PMV. The PMV model is, thus, not applicable in a museum in the tropical country of Malaysia, because a slight increase in the neutral operative temperature could allow significant energy saving. An acceptable neutral temperature was determined. Different energy-saving strategies suitable for a museum in the tropics were also discussed.

sec.title: Indoor Environment
sec.p: Table 3 shows statistical summaries of the indoor measurements for the Galleries A, B, C and D in the National Museum of Malaysia. These include air temperature, radiant temperature, operative temperature, RH, air velocity, effective temperature (ET), standard effective temperature (SET), TSENS, PMV and PPD.

The mean air temperatures of the four sampling zones were: 18.4, 17.7, 21.1 and 18.4°C. The minimum and the maximum air temperature in °C of the zones were: (17.7, 19.2), (16.6, 18.7), (20.8, 21.4) and (17.8, 19.4), respectively. Air temperature at certain points in Gallery A, Gallery B and Gallery D and the mean air temperature in Gallery B were below the lower limit of the temperature range of 18–22°C as recommended by Museums Australia Victoria [16]. This simply indicates that in Malaysia, a country with a warm climate, the occupants would feel a cooler sensation, especially in Gallery B and at certain areas of Gallery A and Gallery D. This was further supported by the subjective questionnaire survey of adaptive thermal comfort. Energy was used unnecessarily to produce excessive A/C.

The mean MRT in the four galleries were 24.5°C, 23.3°C, 25.0°C and 23.9°C. The lowest MRT was 22.6°C at a point in Gallery B and the highest MRT was 25.4°C at a point in Gallery C. The minimum and the maximum RH in the four zones were (60.9%, 63.3%), (62.3%, 68.9%), (73.2%, 75.1%) and (65.8%, 71.8%); the mean RH were 62.6%, 65.3%, 72.4% and 69.4%, respectively. The humidity value of Gallery A was less than 65% RH. It was mentioned earlier that suitable thermo-hygrometric conditions for artefacts and occupants require the lowest acceptable temperature with the maximum admissible RH. Note that the ASHRAE Handbook 2007 suggests a temperature range of 15–25°C and a RH of less than 60% for a general museum [12]. This indicates that the air temperature measured was within the lowest acceptable threshold limit recommended by ASHRAE [12]. However, the RH exceeds the threshold limit recommended by the just mentioned standard. Hence, in the examined cases, it is clear that the strategy of the lowest acceptable temperature with the maximum possible RH is used to design the HVAC system in the National Museum.

Hong Kong has a warm and humid climate. Thus, buildings there require cooling throughout almost the whole year [28]. The indoor design temperature and RH in a modern museum in Hong Kong are 24 ± 1°C and 55 ± 5% [28]. According to Ascione [3] and Bellia [15], the RH should be 50 ± 5% RH for exhibition rooms. Ambient RH must never fall below 40–65% irrespective of the HVAC system and the seasons [15]. With a temperature >20°C, RH > 65% intensifies the development of mycete colonies and promotes the life cycle of harmful insects. Energy savings of 40% can be obtained by changing the indoor RH range from 50 ± 2% to 50 ± 10% [3]. The limiting values of RH for summer conditions in a museum environment according to ANSI/ASHRAE Standard 55 are 50% and 65% [17].

Only the RH of Gallery A is permissible with a great reservation, while the other galleries have significantly too high RH, thus potentially damaging the artefacts. It is obvious that the A/C system of the museum is not functioning properly in terms of humidity control. It is recommended to keep a control of the indoor RH of the National Museum of the tropical country, Malaysia, at 55 ± 5% in order to achieve moderate preservation of the display materials, comfort of the occupants and rational use of energy.

The mean air velocities of the four zones measured were 0.14, 0.14, 0.15 and 0.15 m·s−1. These are within the acceptable range of 0.10–0.25 m·s−1 for a museum as recommended by ANSI/ASHRAE Standard 55 [17]. The average air velocities suitable for the artwork conservation and the occupants’ thermal comfort lie within the range of 0.1–0.15 m·s−1 [29]. Air velocity of less than 0.15 m·s−1 is considered as low-air-movement [30]. Huh et al. showed that low air flow rates with RH below the upper comfort limit allow for less energy consumption [31]. The mean air velocities of the four zones are fairly acceptable.

sec.title: Thermal Sensation
sec.p:
Figure 2 indicates the distribution of frequency for TSENS responses. Figure 3 is the comparative illustration of TSENS response frequency of the four galleries of the museum. Just a few occupants in the four galleries felt cold, adding up to 4%. No one in the four galleries reported feeling hot. The conditions described as slightly cool, neutral and slightly warm are considered acceptable. In all 32% of occupants of the four galleries felt that the inside condition was comfortable, which is neutral. In all 32% of occupants felt slightly cool and 14% of occupants felt slightly warm inside the galleries. Only a few occupants felt that the indoor condition was not comfortable, including 4% of occupants felt cold, 7% of occupants felt cool and 11% of occupants felt warm. Figure 2
Frequency of thermal sensation responses for the National Museum. Figure 3
Comparison of the frequency of thermal sensation responses of different museum galleries and their total percentage.

The mean metabolism and the mean clothing insulation in each gallery was 1.7 met and 0.47 clo, respectively. The mean metabolism, 1.7 met was higher than the value of 1.2 met for light activity level, which is considered as standard for the indoor environment of a museum [32]. Still the subjects were biased to cooler sensation as the mean clothing insulation, 0.47 clo was less than the standard clothing level, 0.5 clo for the cooling season [32]. Moreover, the subjects were free to put on or take off their clothes to adjust their clothing insulation during the questionnaire survey.

The mean thermal sensation vote (MTSV) was as shown in Equations (2)–(9): (2)For Gallery A,MTSV=0.5401T0-11.605 (3)For Gallery B,MTSV=0.2819T0-6.6335 (4)For Gallery C,MTSV=1.0148T0-22.462 (5)For Gallery D,MTSV=0.4572T0-10.481

The PMV was: (6)For Gallery A,PMV=0.1602T0-3.5975 (7)For Gallery B,PMV=0.2713T0-5.9641 (8)For Gallery C,PMV=0.2467T0-5.4631 (9)For Gallery D,PMV=0.2512T0-5.5994 where T0 indicates the operative temperature.

Solution of Equations (2)–(9) for both MTSV and PMV would give the neutrality value. A zero PMV value would denote a thermally comfortable environment. The neutral operative temperature calculated from the MTSV by using Equations (2)–(5) was 22.5°C. In contrast, the neutral operative temperature calculated from the PMV by using Equations (6)–(9) was 22.2°C. Hence, the PMV model by Fanger is not appropriate for use in the tropics, because a slight difference of 0.3°C between the predicted and the actual neutral temperature could save a certain amount of energy in the HVAC system.

sec.title: Thermal Preference
sec.p: Assessment of preferred temperature was done by direct answers to the question: “At the present time, would you prefer a warmer, no change or cooler environment?”[33]. From the overall results, 43% of the respondents’ voted for the thermal sensation ranging from slightly cool to cold, while 25% of the respondents’ voted for the thermal sensation ranging from slightly warm to hot. At the same time, 32% of the respondents felt that the current condition was neutral. These results show that 43% of the people prefer a warmer condition, 25% of them prefer a cooler condition, while 32% of the people found the current condition to be comfortable and there was no need to change the environment.

Simple linear regression models were developed incorporating temperature levels with prefer warmer or prefer cooler conditions. Figure 4 shows that the intersection of the two fitted lines gives the preferred temperature to be 22.3°C. This study shows that the MTSV-based neutral operative temperature, 22.5°C, in the museum building was higher than the preferred operative temperature, 22.3°C. Figure 4
Calculation of preferred temperature.

sec.title: Thermal Acceptability
sec.p: The percentage of the total participants in the questionnaire study, who felt that thermal conditions were “acceptable”, makes up the thermal acceptability value [33]. About 78% of the occupants found the current thermal environment acceptable and 22% of occupants felt that the current thermal environment was not acceptable. Votes of −1, 0 and +1 were in the acceptable temperature range that denotes comfort; all other votes indicated discomfort [26].

According to the ASHRAE Standard 55, a thermal environment is considered comfortable if it is accepted by at least 80% of the staff [17]. This study shows that 22% of the occupants were dissatisfied with their environment. Hence, the indoor environment of the museum can be considered as uncomfortable.

However, the level of comfort is a subjective matter and may differ from one person to another depending upon their opinion and individual perception. The ANSI/ASHRAE Standard 55-2004 on “Thermal Environmental Conditions for Human Occupancy” is the basis of the work presented in this section. Besides this, a well-designed HVAC system needs to control temperature, humidity, air motion and radiant sources within specified limits with the consideration of non-environmental factors, such as the occupants’ activity level and dress.

sec.title: Comparison Between Predicted Indices and Observed Data
sec.p:
Figures 5–8 show that there was a difference between the PMV value and the MTSV value for the four different galleries in the museum. The reason is that the heat-balance of the occupants in the museum was being adjusted by other parameters, such as clothing and activity level. People react in different ways to restore their comfort if they feel uneasy with the thermo-hygrometric condition. These behavioural adjustments are not considered in the PMV model. Furthermore, in the field studies, determination of the occupants’ activity level and insulation due to clothing are not accurately possible. Behavioural, physiological and psychological adjustments are not considered in a realistic sense. Figure 7

sec.title: Energy-Saving Strategies
sec.p: All A/C systems are the preferable solution in order to achieve optimal microclimatic conditions, especially ambient RH, for museums. Two types of A/C systems exist for cooling and dehumidification. One is the traditional constant air volume (CAV) system with separate temperature and humidity controls by cooling–reheating, and the other is a dedicated outdoor air system (DOAS) integrated with a CAV system. Both types of systems recover the sensible and latent heat of the exhaust air by adopting enthalpy recovery devices to reduce energy consumption [34]. The DOAS-integrated system is more efficient than the CAV system with regard to reheating if energy consumption is compared. It consumes 60% less power than the CAV system. The fresh air flow rate is regulated by occupant-based demand-controlled ventilation (DCV) [35].

The best performance in RH control is obtained with a system including desiccant wheels, in case that variation of indoor RH greatly affects the artefacts. It is expensive, but an innovative technique that decreases the related equipment costs. The use of DCV is recommended when the sensitivity of the artefacts to RH is insignificant, as it has the lowest payback value. Intermediate features are presented by the system with the enthalpy wheels.

In addition to the energy-saving strategies applicable to the National Museum of Malaysia, passive cooling can be introduced simultaneously through the implementation of surrounding plantation, which will keep the outdoor environment cooler. Besides, a green roof garden could be planted on the top of the museum, which in this way would absorb less solar heat and thus reduce the cooling load for the A/C, consuming less energy.

Environmental and energy targets in a museum include the reduction of energy consumption and CO2 emissions by applying advanced energy features. Renewable energy may be integrated in museum buildings for the enhancement of comfort and improvement of overall quality.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The following conclusions are drawn concerning the conservation of the artefacts and thermal satisfaction of the occupants in the National Museum, Malaysia:
The occupants’ responses has indicated that the thermal conditions did not satisfactory met the ASHRAE Standard 55, because only 78% of the occupants were satisfied with their environment.

The neutral operative temperature calculated by the PMV based on the Fanger’s model was 22.2°C, whereas the MTSV of the questionnaire responses was about 22.5°C. The preferred neutral temperature was approximately 22.3°C.

The thermal adaptation of the people indoors is responsible for the difference in temperature preferred. Usually, an adaptation of the people to the thermal environment takes place by adjustment of other parameters like clothing, windows and air-recirculation fans.

The mean air temperature in Gallery B was below the lower limit of the temperature range of 18–22°C as recommended by Museums Australia Victoria, causing risk to the artefacts as well as creating an uncomfortably cool environment to the occupants.
The mean humidity in three galleries was above 65% RH, which can cause serious damage to the display materials.
The mean air velocity in each gallery was at a satisfactorily low-air-movement of ≤0.15 m·s−1, suitable for considerable energy saving.

The existing HVAC system was not working satisfactorily during the study, requiring re-adjustment of the set-point temperature, and to re-adjust the humidity control to keep the indoor humidity at 55 ± 5% RH in order to ensure moderate energy saving at the minimum indoor air velocity.
The findings of this research with the consideration of occupants’ thermal comfort are useful in designing a low energy consumption HVAC system for museums in tropical countries.
